channel.title: Car stereo
channel.description: When i turn my stereo up above 10 (which isnt even really loud..) my stereo shuts off.. do i need a new stereo or is mine hooked up wrong or what?

item.description:

kyled123:

hi, i dont have an amp or anything, i dont even really know much about this stuff, but all i know is if i turn it up too high ( which still isnt loud at all ) it shuts off then turns back on

You didn’t answer my question, how do you turn it back on? Do you just have to press the power button again? Or do you have to replace a fuse?

item.title: Car stereo
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Now, if the other way around, a big stereo/amp can overload crappy speakers, because the stereo or amp is what is sending out the power, so if the speakers can’t handle it all it can break them.

or more likely with a modern amp, it detects the impedance mismatch and shuts off to protect the speakers… right?

or did i dream this, cuz it sounds like it would be a good idea and i was pretty sure it exists, heh

Read full topic

item.title: Car stereo
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

xx matty xx:

have you made any modifications to the speaker system in your car, or is it all default? your speakers may be drawing more current than the amp can safely provide, especially if you’re using the default shitty amp with sexy big-ass speakers.

Speakers don’t “draw power”, you could put the biggest speakers in the world hooked up to a 20watt stereo and, if 20 watts was enough power to drive them at all it would do it and it would just be very quiet. The speakers wouldn’t blow any fuses or overwork the amp or anything, it just doesn’t work like that.

Now, if the other way around, a big stereo/amp can overload crappy speakers, because the stereo or amp is what is sending out the power, so if the speakers can’t handle it all it can break them.

Read full topic

item.title: Car stereo
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

@OP: Was your sound system installed after-market, or is it the stock headunit/speakers that came with the car? Has this problem always occurred, or did it just start happening recently?

My friend installed his sound system himself, but managed to mess up the connection between the amplifier and his subwoofer, which caused temporary cut-outs when it was drawing too much power. As fate would have it, he had both wires from the sub connected to only one of the contact points on the amp. Whether or not that’s dangerous is beyond me, but it was certainly undermining the ability of the subwoofer to draw power properly.

Read full topic

item.description:
@mwiebelhaus wrote:

[quote=“runescape3dude, post:3, topic:339236”]Seeing as someone has already made a topic about car stereo problems, I will post mine in here…

Ok, the radio in my car only gets the odd number frequencies - like you americans - and in NZ there are virtually no stations on the odd number frequencies, is there any way that I can like change settings in the radio to make it work on even number frequencies? Or will I need to get a new radio? + It ejects all cds as soon as I insert them…[/quote]

Move to the United States, that should solve the problem.
